Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2017 Conference on Computer Aided Verification

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: This travel grant provides supports for 15 US-based students to attend the 29th Conference on Computer-Aided Verification (CAV) to be held in Heidelberg, Germany, on July 24-28th 2017. CAV, one of the premier conference in formal verification, is dedicated to the advancement of the theory and practice of computer-aided formal analysis and synthesis methods for hardware and software systems. The conference covers the spectrum from theoretical results to concrete applications, with an emphasis on practical verification tools and the algorithms and techniques that are needed for their implementation. Conferences like CAV are a near-unique opportunity for graduate students to attend technical presentations, interact with the leading researchers in the field, and receive valuable feedback on their research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Formal Verification is concerned with rigorous mathematical techniques to ensure the correct functioning of the software and computer systems our lives are so dependent on today. As with other branches of computer science, there are various annual meetings called conferences, where the leading researchers of the field come together to present their latest results. While participation is open to all, there is non-trivial participation cost associated with such events.

The major goal of this project was to attract junior US-based doctoral students to attend the main conference in the field of Formal Verification, known as CAV ("Computer Aided Verification"), in 2017. This edition of the conference took place in Heidelberg, Germany, in the second half of July. Particular targets were students who otherwise may not have the means for attending, typically because the cost of traveling overseas is too high. The means for creating an attractor is a fellowship that reduces the financial burden of attendance. The present NSF project supplied funds to support such fellowships for select students.

At the same time the goal was to extend the opportunities for CAV attendance to disadvantaged groups, such as students from smaller universities (with less available funding on their own) and from underrepresented communities, which in Formal Verification includes women and people with a non-white ethnic background.

The Project was able to offer support for attendance to nine students to the conference. Several of these were not invited to present their research at the conference (which typically makes other funding available) and would thus very likely not have attended the conference without the Fellowship. Thanks to the generous support provided by the NSF, we were able to accommodate all applications.

With two exceptions, the students were in the first or second year of their PhD program and thus qualified as "junior". The students came from three different ethnic backgrounds, roughly equally distributed: Asian (not Asian-American), Latin-American, and US. Unfortunately we were not able to attract (many) applications from underrepresented groups: most of the Fellowship applicants came from major US schools (U Penn, UIUC, UCB, etc), and all of them were men.

We share some feedback (slightly edited for brevity and relevance) communicated to us from the Fellowship recipients:

  • attending CAV was a wonderful opportunity that I think was very helpful to my growth as an aspiring researcher
  • opportunities to chat with other formal methods researchers was very valuable to me; I received a lot of good advice for the job search
  • CAV is one of the premier conferences in the field of hardware and software systems verification; the fellowship added to the motivation to participate and learn
  • having many interesting questions almost after every talk indicates the quality of the work being presented and also, the active participation of the audience
  • would like to thank the National Science Foundation and the CAV 2017 PC Chairs for enabling me to attend this conference
  • as my first conference, I believe CAV 2017 served as an important milestone in my academic career
  • Overall, I greatly enjoyed CAV as a networking event and as a chance to learn about the general direction of the formal methods community. I believe it has given me a better idea of how to be a productive researcher
